title: DNS rebinding in --inspect (insufficient fix of CVE-2022-32212 affecting macOS devices)
content:
The fix for CVE-2022-32212, covered the cases for routable IP addresses, however, there exists a specific behavior on macOS devices when handling the http://0.0.0.0 URL that allows an attacker-controlled DNS server to bypass the DNS rebinding protection by resolving hosts in the .local domain.
Original HackerOne report
Node.js Blog
Impact
Attacker with access to a compromised DNS server or the ability to spoof its responses can gain access to the Node.js debugger, which can result in remote code execution.
Trick a macOS user into visiting a malic: //0.0.0.0 URL to bypass DNS rebinding protection.
vuln_description: The vulnerability involves a DNS rebinding attack in Node.js's --inspect feature, specifically affecting macOS devices. The fix for CVE-2022-32212 did not account for the behavior of http://0.0.0.0 URLs on macOS, allowing an attacker-controlled DNS server to bypass DNS rebinding protection by resolving hosts in the .local domain. This can lead to remote code execution via the Node.js debugger.
reason: This vulnerability requires understanding of DNS rebinding attacks, the specific behavior of macOS with http://0.0.0.0 URLs, and the interaction between these components to bypass the protection. The attack also involves manipulating the DNS resolution process and exploiting a non-obvious interaction in the Node.js debugger's protection mechanism.
